message_1: A company needs to select a team of 5 employees from a group of 10 employees to work on a project. In how many ways can the company select the team if one of the employees, Tom, must be on the team?
message_2:
Since Tom must be on the team, we are left with selecting 4 more employees from the remaining 9 employees (10 total employees minus Tom). This is a combination problem, as the order of selection does not matter. We can use the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of employees to choose from (9 in this case) and k is the number of employees to select (4 in this case).

C(9, 4) = 9! / (4!(9-4)!)
C(9, 4) = 9! / (4!5!)
C(9, 4) = 362880 / (24 * 120)
C(9, 4) = 362880 / 2880
C(9, 4) = 126

So, there are 126 ways to select a team of 5 employees with Tom on the team.
